channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Judge’s Family Denies Pride Was Behind Rejection of 3rd-Highest Award
item.description: The survivors of Jagdish Sharan Verma, who was instrumental in strengthening laws protecting women, said he wouldn’t have accepted any award had he been alive.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA

item.title: World Briefing: British Nuclear Reprocessing Plant Detected Elevated Radiation Levels
item.description: The high levels were caused by naturally occurring background radon, not by any faults at the aging plant, the operating company said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Bloomberg Picked to Be Climate Envoy
item.description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City, has a new job: United Nations special envoy for cities and climate change.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: 17 Soldiers Killed in Ambushes in Yemen
item.description: Gunmen attacked a checkpoint and a police patrol on Friday in eastern Yemen, killing 17 soldiers, military and security officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Aid Groups Warn of Food Crisis in Mali
item.description: The agencies said Friday that more than 800,000 people in northern Mali needed immediate food aid and that three million people nationwide were at risk.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Israeli Military Strikes Targets in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military said it struck a plant for weapons manufacturing, a weapons storage site and what it called a “terror activity site.”
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Violence in Central African Republic’s Capital Alarms Red Cross
item.description: Attacks in Bangui have reached “unprecedented levels” with at least 30 people killed in the past three days, humanitarian officials said.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Is Said to Plan Fence-Mending Trip to Saudi Arabia
item.description: An official said President Obama would seek to reassure King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia after a period of tension over American policies toward Iran and Syria.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: On 35th Anniversary of Diplomatic Ties With U.S., China Tries to Soften Image
item.description: China has moved to expand friendly cultural exchanges with the United States and promote a series of prominent collaborations in music, dance and education, particularly in New York.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A man in Beijing turned away on Friday after setting off firecrackers to celebrate the start of the Chinese New Year.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Even Out of Office, a Wielder of Great Power in Yemen
item.description: Ali Abdullah Saleh, Yemen’s former president, is a rarity in the Arab world: an autocrat overthrown by popular revolt who nonetheless remains in his country, undisturbed.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:credit: Hani Mohammed/Associated Press, Photo from September 2012
item.media:description: “These people are not confident of their power, and still consider themselves as employees of Ali Abdullah Saleh,” Saleh said of his critics.

item.title: Abuse Claims in Ukraine Rise Among Protesters
item.description: After being missing for a week, an antigovernment protest leader stumbled out of a forest and said he had been crucified, raising concerns over abuses in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: An opposition supporter held a Ukrainian flag as he warmed himself next to a fire near Kiev's Independence Square in Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Are You Ready for Some ... Nordic Voices?
item.description: In New York during the big game, many non-football events are scheduled, like a Carnegie Hall concert and standup comedy at Dangerfield’s.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES BARRON
item.media:credit: Jacob Hannah for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Nordic Voices, a group from Norway that is scheduled to perform Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, rehearsing in Burlington, Vt., on Friday. From left are Ingrid Hanken, Ebba Rydh, Trond Reinholdtsen and Frank Havry. Told that their date coincided with the Super Bowl, Mr. Havry recalled, the group said, “Super what?”

item.title: France and Britain Agree on Outer Space, but Find No Common Ground on Europe
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain wants to revise the European Union’s rule book, but President François Hollande of France says no.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, left, and President François Hollande of France with a mock-up of a drone project.

item.title: Syrian Talks, Ending First Round, Fail Even to Agree on Easing Aid Blockade
item.description: The first round of peace negotiations ended without agreement over the easing of the Syrian government’s blockade of humanitarian aid to besieged communities.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Syria’s foreign minister, Walid al-Moallem, center, said Friday in Geneva that he did not rule out returning for more negotiations.

item.title: Give Malta Your Tired and Huddled, and Rich
item.description: A Mediterranean island is in search of wealthy foreigners with the means to buy citizenship and bring the government some cash.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Amanda Knox, Found Guilty in Italy Killing, Vows to Fight Extradition
item.description: The latest court decision is likely to set off years more of court battles in Italy and possibly the United States, legal experts said.
item.dc:creator: By ERIK ECKHOLM
item.media:description: Robin Roberts, left, interviewed Amanda Knox on ABC’s “Good Morning America” on Friday.

item.title: As Argentine Peso Falters, President Keeps a Low Profile
item.description: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner has said very little about the crisis that has led the nation’s currency to plunge.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:credit: Anibal Adrian Greco for The New York Times
item.media:description: People lined up outside a bank to buy dollars in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

item.title: Musharraf’s Request to Leave Pakistan for Treatment Is Rejected
item.description: Lawyers said a special court issued arrest warrants in the treason case against the former leader Pervez Musharraf and directed him to appear in court to be formally charged.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Sorting Through the Rubble of Museum of Islamic Art in Cairo
item.description: Experts sort painstakingly through the Museum of Islamic Art in Cairo, devastated by a truck bomb attack last month at police headquarters across the street.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH GAUCH
item.media:credit: Ed Giles for The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck bomb blast on Jan. 24 tore through the 111-year-old Museum of Islamic Art in Cairo, blowing out windows and sending metal and glass flying through its halls.

item.title: A Leader Shows Vulnerability in Turkey’s Cash Crisis
item.description: Turkey’s problems extend past bond purchases and interest rates to questions about the stability of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is at odds with Turkey’s central bank over how to reverse problems with the currency.

item.title: Verdict in March for 3 in France Accused of Intent to Fight in Syria
item.description: The three young men, accused of violating a French antiterrorism law, were caught in 2012 as they tried to fly to Turkey and eventually join the Syrian rebellion.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Inflation in Euro Zone Falls, and a 12% Jobless Rate Doesn’t Budge
item.description: Joblessness remained at 12 percent in December while inflation dipped, suggesting the central bank will be under pressure to provide more stimulus.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Job applicants enter a government-run employment office in Madrid last week.

item.title: Scarlett Johansson and Oxfam, Torn Apart by Israeli Company Deal
item.description: The actress’s endorsement of a company with a factory in an area of the West Bank that Palestinians envision as part of a future independent state has created an international political storm.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: SodaStream has a factory in a West Bank settlement.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 31
item.description: Members of the Chinese community performing a lion dance as part of Chinese New Year celebrations in Kolkata, West Bengal.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Members of the Chinese community performing a lion dance as they celebrate the Chinese New Year in Kolkata, West Bengal.

item.title: The Lede: A Dutch Jihadist in Syria Speaks, and Blogs
item.description: A Dutchman who quit the Royal Netherlands Army to join the jihad in Syria explains himself on Tumblr and in an English-language interview this week on Dutch television.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: "Half of Jihad is media." A Dutch jihadist's Tumblr photograph of the weapons he uses in Syria: His knife, his gun and his Instagram account.
